statement.tex: %text Find the distance of the point ${\small(-1,-5,-10)}$, from the point of intersection of the line $\ora{r}=(\vector{2}{-1}{2})+\lambda(\vector{3}{4}{2})$ and the plane $\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{1}{-1}{1})=5$. %

step.context: %text What are the possible intersections, if any, of a line and a plane? %
step.tex: %text a point, a line, a plane. %
step.reason: %text A line and a plane can intersect in either a{\bf point}, a{\bf line}, or have{\bf no intersection}. If the line is parallel to the plane, but there is distance between them, there is no intersection. However if a line lies on the plane their intersection is the line itself. If none of the above scenarios are true then the intersection is the point at which the line passes through the plane. %

step.context: %text If $\ora{r}=(\vector{2}{-1}{2})+\lambda(\vector{3}{4}{2})$ represents a point on the line and $\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{1}{-1}{1})=5$ represents a point on the plane, what is the condition for these two to be the same point? %
step.reason: %text The point of intersection of the line and plane must satisfy both of their equations. Therefore, if we substitute $\ora{r}$ from the definition of the line into the plane, we satisfy both. % {\small\left((\vector{2}{-1}{2})+\lambda(\vector{3}{4}{2})\right) \cdot(\vector{1}{-1}{1})=5}
